On Thu, 2008-09-18 at 08:21 -0400, toalexsmail wrote:
> this approach force me to write one more class, and I can't run only
> some methods within the class.

No doubt you'll find that it makes sense to separate those tests anyway.
Think of it like JUnit forcing you to use good programming practices. If
you have a test suite where you can identify two disparate groups of
tests that you would like to run separately, you obviously have two
suites in one file. 

I wrote a suite recently that tested a particular class containing both
CRUD operations and single search operation. The search tests grew
exponentially (as they tend to) and quickly outnumbered all the other
tests combined! Eventually I had to concede that in that case it made
sense for one suite to test everything but the search.... and another
that was just the search.

Gabriel.
